there have to be users who will seed all optional files in order all files are accessible. (open site/merger site (0) menu, scroll down and click "Download and help distribute all files") and set appropriate maximum filesize. And i think users should have right to delete their site content even from other people machines. Anyone can still do regular backups of /data folder so he can return in history and manually recover deleted data.

Bitcoin is mineable where javascript is accepted, so also on ZeroNet sites. You can see @styromaniac list of such sites [here](/1NominErMMEodukCTKD5NN6HqgmtsG4Z8U/). If someone made a Monero mining javascript, then it should work.

@~Publicality~: they do not  :) many files have no peer, i think it is big problem in numerous sites. They are wasting users time to show content that can not be downloaded.
Dynamic sites like IFS support optional files, it means it is downloaded only after user request to see image/video etc. If you watch only part of the video and close page, you may end up with incomplete file. Some sites has "Seed" button which should cause complete file download. To help seed many files user has to buy large HDD and open site's (0) menu (drag&drop button in corner on each site) and click to Download all optional files. Some sites using merger kind of sites to distribute data. For example zerome. When you search zerome in sites menu on ZeroHello page, you can find some hubs, open such hub, then its (0) menu and you can distribute only this hub files. But note you may download also bad content.

mcdev in [/dev board on Millchan](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/?:users/12NPW6WLFBLVivNGqijcfktARobftfLFAN:dev:b217cc91-d5c0-49bb-bba4-0117c9922152) recently replied user who had similar issue claiming the cause is when you help distribute some site files, it can cause slow down because of ZN being single threaded. That should change (per the recent @nofish [blog post](/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post:142:Changelog:+December+13,+2018))
Btw. i see this issue too recentz days, i am DLing one large site (DL all optional files option) and all zites are very very slow to react.

I hope developers will create system which will significantly decrease importance of the site owner, meaning visitors will be able to [modetate site content](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/1086) so the site quality will not depend upon single point of failure (site owner) to be cleaning the site.

**Problem discovering zite owner IP**
But maybe the problem described by @publicality is not that big, because i think it is rather impossible to discover which peer among thousands in the P2P network CREATED a site and first published it to the first peer. If you are third peer, how would you know the site is new? If it has low peer count, it does not mean it is new right? After lets say 2 years if some powerful people weant to discover original owner of the site with lets say 100+ peers, how would they do it? (i do not say it is impossible..)
They may have better chance if owner publish new changes on site and if their IPs/peers makes majority of the site peers.. Maybe they can say there is probability some IP is the owner, then they would have to hack the ISP of this IP to discover who is renting the IP....The IP can be shared among multiple computers in the building.  Site owner can use encryption on the device where he store zeronet /data. The IP can be a VPN server IP with "no logging" policy..
LIke with clernet sites, we can not 100% trust site owner i think.

thx for sharing users.json backup script for Linux.

Regarding apostrophes ('), you can try to replace them here by: \

Also it may be handy to include in the script a command which will delete backups older than X days. Maybe something like this (untested, files older 180 days):
find $backups -iname \*users.json\* -mtime +180 -exec rm {} \;
or
find $backups -name "\*users.json\*" -mtime +180 -delete

ps: to make it run at boot, what can work may be this:
$ crontab -e
then append the line:
@reboot /path/to/scriptname &
and also setting appropriate permissions to the script:
$ chmod 755 /path/to/scriptname

Another option to prevent data loss would be to get a big HDD and setup automated backups not to loose the data. Some people use network attached storage (NAS) to prevent situation of HDD failure - these devices usually utilize multiple HDDs in RAID so the overal storage will survive single or multiple drive failure.

The tracker URL have to contain port (example: :443). Valid URL is:
https://1.tracker.eu.org:443/announce
https://2.tracker.eu.org:443/announce
https://3.tracker.eu.org:443/announce

if the url is not https but http, then the port is likely :80
